html:
7.29.18  4:13 pm   5.16.16  6:57 am so what happened to that album?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201605160657

5.16.16  6:57 am   i noticed you say that you spent about 2 years writing non-stop. does this mean you don't write anymore, and are just creating the songs you wrote before? or do you still write?

     the short ones for vine were mostly written new. but anything of length was written way before. for example, crazy/raining = 2011. school = 2010. write a song on the count of 3 = 2009. in 2014 i started focusing on recording, and also really discovered video, etc. But i am planning do an album this year, so it means i will be going back into the writing archives
original_html: 7.29.18  4:13 pm   5.16.16  6:57 am so what happened to that album?

html:
7.28.18  5:38 pm   When I'm writing a song, or making anything, it's interesting to mutate ideas around and create many iterations. This can be good, but Im often too afraid to judge which is best or even commit to any one idea before moving on. if I come up with too many, the original idea i was excited about gets diluted and feels lame. So what're some key questions I could ask myself to find the best solution? its very hard not to get hung up on small bits, but I want move on and make something bigger than that. Thank you for your advice.

completely different strategy
original_html:
7.28.18  5:38 pm   When I'm writing a song, or making anything, it's interesting to mutate ideas around and create many iterations. html:
7.28.18  11:44 am   7.27.18  9:50 am   While those numbers are rigid, by definition, any tone can be defined as a rational or irrational fraction of an octave, so literally any note you sing can be described as some fraction (though many with uncomputable irrational numbers).


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201807270950

7.27.18  9:50 am   7.26.18  5:36 pm So you're saying that you're willing to use non-rigid tones (3/2 tones, 16/432 tones, even πth tones etc.), if need be?
